title: There are lots of ways to kill someone anonymously. Why did Russia try to kill a former agent on British soil using Novichok, a nerve agent developed by Russia, causing all fingers to be pointed at Russia? - Quora

response.answer_text:
To send a message. To keep international tensions simmering. To distract Russian citizens from domestic problems that the head of state hasn’t addressed in his eighteen-year reign. To maintain power.  There was no direct benefit in poisoning UK citizen Skripal, his Russian daughter, a British first responder, and two unlucky bystanders. Skripal was exchanged to the UK in 2010, and if he had had any valuable secrets to reveal, would have done so years ago, although he was working with Western intelligence. In any such operation, those who ordered it are prepared for a range of results. If Skripal had died alone and it was ruled a heart attack or unknown causes, well at least it is one of a string of such deaths, and looking like a possible Kremlin hit to anyone paying attention. But whether the target dies or not, if the chemical agent is identified, then everyone knows the Russian state was involved. If the assassins are identified or caught, all the more so. If innocent bystanders are harmed or murdered by a Russian weapon of mass destruction used indiscriminately in a foreign state, it will only improve the odds that the message is heard. The message is: To ordinary Russians: it’s the Cold War all over again, the West slanders us as murderers, enemies, traitors, and fifth-columnists deserving to be murdered are everywhere, our murdering is justified, we are an important and powerful state, and we are sending our soldiers to fight the enemy on their own soil. Never mind about the flat economy that we weren’t competent to manage and your rising retirement age, support your strongman president-for-life.To the rest of the world: make your statements of protest, expel our spies and diplomats, apply more of your pathetic sanctions that only help us to maintain a siege mentality, abuse human rights at home, and cluster around Dear Leader.To Russian state and security people: you’re working for gangsters, we own you for life, don’t betray us, we’ll kill you, we’ll use all of the state’s resources, the law and our own promises mean nothing to us.This is what expert on international crime and Russian security Mark Galeotti calls dark power.  Not that the Russian state is playing three-dimensional chess, or anything like that. The agency that attempted the failed Skripal assassination, commonly known as the GRU, probably couldn’t be trusted to keep a surprise party secret from a six-year-old. They have a record of public failures: Leonid Bershidsky, “Putin’s Swashbuckling Spies Are Hurting Him,” in Bloomberg, 2018-09-05.In this light, they are open to ridicule: Seriously, the alleged Skripal poisoners might as well have been wearing big stickers on their backs that said "RUSSIAN GOONS," smoking Belomorkanals and eating sunflower seeds pic.twitter.com/zELW70IQfI— max seddon (@maxseddon) September 5, 2018
  On the other hand, as I mentioned, in planning such an operation, one anticipates a range of possible results. These are not super spies. Not KGB. They are military intelligence. A worrying + problematic new narrative is emerging that #Russia's #GRU are somehow a bunch of bunglers (incl Ben Wallace: "more Johnny English than James Bond")Inaccurate + miss point. GRU ethos about taking chances to not miss opportunities, even if won't always succeed— Mark Galeotti (@MarkGaleotti) September 6, 2018
 They are conducting operations against their enemy, going for possible results, and considering their risk assessment, as if in wartime. Being identified as an attack by the Russian Federation on UK soil was either an acceptable risk, or an objective.

According to the British authorities on March 4, 2018, the former GRU officer and English spy , 66-year-old Sergei Skripal and his 33-year-old daughter Yulia, were poisoned in the English city of Salisbury by poison agent A234 ("Novichok"). This provoked the largest international scandal, as London accused Russia. Against the Russian Federation, sanctions were imposed, including by the United States. Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova, commenting on Theresa May's statement, described what was happening in the British parliament as a "circus show," noting that London had embarked on another information and political campaign based on provocation. Zakharova urged the British authorities to disclose the results of the investigation of the cases of Litvinenko, Boris Berezovsky, Alexander Perepelichny and many others who mysteriously died in Britain. On May 25, the Russian Embassy in London demanded that the UK apologize for accusations on the "case of the Skripal ".
